channel.title: Nyphrex - 530 Emulation Project
channel.description:
Hi guys, I'm new here so please be gentle. Nyphrex is a revision 530 Runescape Emulation project derived from [url=http://www.rune-server.org/runescape-development/rs-503-client-server/downloads/492138-scapeemulator.html]ScapeEmulator[/url] created by Graham and his brother Jonneh. The goal for the project is to create a 530 remake that utilizes fancy technology to provide a unique and rewarding experience for our customers. There isn't much to report, most of this is a work in progress. Please enjoy the pictures below of what the environment looks like and also the cow.
[u]Leachers[/u]
- Davidi2
[u]Team[/u]
- Heist - Sini
[u]Media[/u]
[img width=800]http://i2.minus.com/iZPvfN3i6XhD6.png[/img]
[img width=800]http://t3.gstatic.com/images?q=tbn:ANd9GcSjdrjbjIvYBQdB360xZ-hkMT1F5B9DHg2Ympi9tM97zi9cZEHO7w[/img]

item.title: Nyphrex - 530 Emulation Project
item.dc:creator: @davidi2 Davidi2
item.description:
@davidi2 wrote:

[quote=“AtomicInt_, post:127, topic:544121”]—[/quote]Like I said in the later post, I know that wasn’t a solid design (saying that it was similar to what shit servers use) and strictly something you could do with the least amount of modifying of the scape-emu source to reduce the amount of repetition and keep the packet structure obfuscation in one place per type and help with polymorphism for the messages. I understand what it accomplishes. I just don’t see why it’s hard to understand what I’m saying, in that it seems like a waste to have this go through a scripting language when it’s so simple. Scapeemu even comes with all the enums you’d require to use in some sort of mapped queue or chain decoder.

[quote=“sinisoul, post:128, topic:544121”]Yeah that’s a solid explanation. I mean if you really cared David you’d look in the code, pulled examples, quoted source files. But everyone isn’t perfect yaknow.[/quote]First rate asshole

Anyway, I’ll leave your topic alone now.

Read full topic

@sinisoul wrote:

Yeah that’s a solid explanation. I mean if you really cared David you’d look in the code, pulled examples, quoted source files. But everyone isn’t perfect yaknow.

Read full topic

item.title: Nyphrex - 530 Emulation Project
item.dc:creator: @ExtremeX-Scape Ryley
item.description:
@ExtremeX-Scape wrote:

[quote=“Davidi2, post:120, topic:544121”][quote author=sinisoul link=topic=662998.msg4454227#msg4454227 date=1413670439]

[quote author=Davidi2 link=topic=662998.msg4454225#msg4454225 date=1413669559]

But aren’t there only a few cases like that one?

…no, all packets have streams like this and theres many MANY packets that have a similar model to this. it’s not fun to work with if you’re designing a decoder for each packet
[/quote]But don’t you have to get the structure of each one anyway to add its definition to your normalizer? I don’t really see the advantage, it seems like it does exactly the same thing as scape emulator already did with the message structure.

Yes but it’s more dynamic and if you wanted to you could easily generate your own obfuscated streams and apply them to your client. There’s a lot of different advantages. It’s really not. I just don’t think I explained it well enough. It makes working with the client substantially easier. Scape emulator has 5 different decoders for the same packet structure. So no David, no even remotely close.
[/quote]You would have 5 different decoder definitions as well, wouldn’t you? Just all into a script instead of into a new class. You could create one decoder to achieve the same thing in Scape emulator with a simple switch statement and slight modification of how you bind the decoders (allowing for multiple ID’s).

int id; int data; switch(option) { ONE: id = getByteA; data = getMEInt; break; TWO: id = getInt; data = getNegByte; break; // etc... } return new RandomThingMessage(id, data); Allowing you to change it rather simply. You could create some sort of generic or vararg to define what a packet decoder SHOULD return if you wanted to ensure structure was not changed accidentally… But yeah.[/quote]

This isn’t even close to what this design accomplishes. When transmitting frames they first get passed through their ‘normalizer’ codec which normalizes the streams, deobfuscating them and sorting them by their length.

Taking your example:

int id; int data; switch(option) { ONE: id = getByteA; data = getMEInt; break; TWO: id = getInt; data = getNegByte; break; // etc... } return new RandomThingMessage(id, data);

Code like this will never been seen, say you have those two frames, normalized they would both have the same structure, when handling them there wouldn’t be a need to read different obfuscated streams for each option in this case, they would be the same. This reduces a lot of the verbosity that tags along with obfuscated frames.

e.g:

var option = ... int id = get int data = getInt return new RandomThingMessage(id, data);

Read full topic

item.title: Nyphrex - 530 Emulation Project
item.dc:creator: @davidi2 Davidi2
item.description:
@davidi2 wrote:

I literally just talked about lowering decoder and encoder files by merging repeated patterns. The concept is so simple to implement (even a better design one than the simple switch statement example I gave) in the primary language of the application, I just want to see how shifting the task over to a script, adding more steps, is going to be advantageous. That’s why I asked for the comparisons, so you can show why your way is better.

Read full topic

item.title: Nyphrex - 530 Emulation Project
item.dc:creator: @sinisoul sini
item.description:
@sinisoul wrote:

I don’t think you even still understand what it does so why bother coming up with a list of premises. Main reason why I created this system is so that I follow the DRY paradigm, and keep the amount of class decoder/encoder files to a minimum.

Read full topic

item.title: Nyphrex - 530 Emulation Project
item.dc:creator: @davidi2 Davidi2
item.description:
@davidi2 wrote:

[quote=“sinisoul, post:123, topic:544121”][quote]
I’m pretty sure it’s been done by shit servers for years in their packet handlers.
[/quote]

It’s not the same in the sense that you just normalize the data input then you parse it. Usually people bundle it together. I’ve explained this though so I don’t know why you’re bringing up it’s not ‘unique’ or ‘new’. It is, it’s a new approach to the pipeline and it makes defining, decoding, encoding, packets easier which is a good chunk of making development more efficient.

Lothy said though, make sure it’s worth it

It is? I mean, why wouldn’t it be? It’s a pretty integral part of the pipeline.[/quote]
When you add more steps to an “integral part of the pipeline”, that increases the chances of it not being worth it, not the other way around. I mean, that’s like saying ECCM is always worth it. In concept it sounds like because you’re adding another step of verification it’s going to be good, but there are always downsides. Point being, you have to show why yours is better besides simply saying “it’s easier” without giving any sort of comparison. Pros, cons, code comparison, etc.

[quote=“sinisoul, post:123, topic:544121”][quote]
I think it would be interesting to see it actually integrated in the client, having the structures actually saved somewhere or sent on connection, rather than being hard coded all over the place.
[/quote]
I agree but that’s more of a ‘when we need it we’ll design it’ sort of task. If botting became an issue, I would implement this.[/quote]Alrighty then.

Anyway, I digress. RSPS is all about developing what you enjoy. If you find this concept interesting and want to pursue it, I’m not trying to stop you. I was trying to bait out some critical thinking.

Read full topic

item.title: Nyphrex - 530 Emulation Project
item.dc:creator: @sinisoul sini
item.description:
@sinisoul wrote:

I'm pretty sure it's been done by shit servers for years in their packet handlers.

It’s not the same in the sense that you just normalize the data input then you parse it. Usually people bundle it together. I’ve explained this though so I don’t know why you’re bringing up it’s not ‘unique’ or ‘new’. It is, it’s a new approach to the pipeline and it makes defining, decoding, encoding, packets easier which is a good chunk of making development more efficient.

Lothy said though, make sure it's worth it

It is? I mean, why wouldn’t it be? It’s a pretty integral part of the pipeline.

I think it would be interesting to see it actually integrated in the client, having the structures actually saved somewhere or sent on connection, rather than being hard coded all over the place.

I agree but that’s more of a ‘when we need it we’ll design it’ sort of task. If botting became an issue, I would implement this.

Read full topic

item.title: Nyphrex - 530 Emulation Project
item.dc:creator: @davidi2 Davidi2
item.description:
@davidi2 wrote:

I’m just trying to point out that the concept isn’t really new or unique, I’m pretty sure it’s been done by shit servers for years in their packet handlers. They’ll create a class for the item packets, group similar ones together in certain methods, and have a switch that makes it easy to see the different packet structures. Obviously its a simplistic and sometimes poorly conceived design, if you want to expand on the concept by having a better design revolve around it and switch it over to scripting, by all means. Like Lothy said though, make sure it’s worth it. I think it would be interesting to see it actually integrated in the client, having the structures actually saved somewhere or sent on connection, rather than being hard coded all over the place.

Read full topic
